History of Present Illness:
Patient seen and examined, agree with house officer admission 
note by Dr. ___ ___ with additions below. 

___ year old Male with ESRD who presents for initiation of 
hemodialysis. He has a history of type 2 diabetes and 
hypertension, which have led to his ESRD. Over the weeks prior 
to admission, he states he has been somewhat short of breath 
with exertion, worsening pedal edema. He also has noted 
depressed appetite and constipation.

Of note the patient is severely anxious of about needles and 
procedures, and requires anxiolytics for any IV access 
procedure.

Brief Hospital Course:
PRIMARY REASON FOR HOSPITALIZATION:

Mr. ___ is a ___ male with PMH of T2DM, HTN, 
hyperlipidemia, and CKD stage 5 who presented to the hospital in 
direct admission to initiate hemodialysis in the setting of 
volume overload and hyperkalemia. He was initiated on HD and 
discharged home to begin outpatient HD.

ACUTE CARE:

1. ESRD, Hyperkalemia As he had no access, his potassium was 
lowered with insulin and kayexelate until HD initiation. Volume 
overload resulted in shortness of breath and pulmonary edema on 
CXR. This was managed with extra doses of ethacrynic acid until 
HD was initiated. ___ placed a tunneled HD line for use until 
fistula matures. PPD was negative and HD initiation labs were 
sent. Hyperkalemia resolved, and volume overload with pulmonary 
edema and SOB had resolved on discharge.

CHRONIC CARE:

#. Type 2 Diabetes Uncontrolled with Complications: continued 
Glargine, ISS coverage, ___ Diet
#. Hyperlipidemia: Consider starting statin once HD has been 
initiated. Defer to outpatient providers
#. Benign Hypertension: continued Amlodipine, carvedilol
#. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: Not currently on CPAP

TRANSITIONS IN CARE:
-will followup with PCP and new HD providers. PPD was negative. 
-Will need Hep B immunizations. 
-will need to consider initiating statin therapy on discharge
-Full Code

received 3 dialysis sessions. You will begin regular outpatient

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more 
than 3 lbs.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o male admitted following partial transplant nephrectomy 
for mass in transplant kidney found on routine screening. Due to 
the complex nature of this case, patient went to the OR with Dr 
___ urology and Dr ___ with Transplant. It was stated 
that due to the complex nature of this case, two attendings were 
present for the case involving Open partial nephrectomy from the 
transplanted kidney.
In summary, the transplanted kidney was completely encased in a 
large amount of scar
tissue making dissection difficult. The tumor was excised, and 
JP drain was placed. Please see the surgical notes of both Dr 
___ Dr ___ details.
In the post op period, his pain was controlled using a PCA. 
Urine output and residual renal function were excellent.
Pathology of the tumor revealed  "Oncocytoma, margin free of 
tumor"
On about POD 6, the patient was noted to be increasingly 
distended. Bowel function was very sluggish post op, in addition 
to a notation on labs of increased WBC as well as development of 
fever. A CT of the abdomen was obtained showing "Moderate grade 
partial small bowel obstruction with transition point noted  
within the right lower quadrant, slightly anterior to the 
transplant kidney."
He was taken back to the OR on ___ again with Dr___ and 
___ for Exploratory laparotomy with lysis of adhesions and 
freeing up obstruction. Per the operative report lysis of 
adhesions of the bowel was done and the finding that the 
terminal ileum had been plastered down to the area of the 
kidney. This was felt to be the transition point seen on CT and 
this was the cause of the obstruction. No bowel perforation was 
found or other evidence of intra-abdominal pathology seen. There 
was a significant amount of fluid encountered when the patient 
was opened. This fluid was sent for culture and lab tests. 
Creatinine was low, so it was not felt to be a urine leak. 
Enterococcus (Vanco sensitive) did grow from the fluid as well 
as from blood cultures obtained the same day. Urine cultures 
from the day previous were also positive for Enterococcus and he 
was started on Vancomycin and Flagyl which were given x 7 days. 
An ID consult was obtained.
He was switched to Ampicillin on ___ and this was continued 
for 9 days. In addition he received Levaquin for a total of 11 
days.
The patient was started on TPN via a PICC line, this was 
continued for about two weeks. PO diet was started back slowly, 
he will be seen as an outpatient by nutrition. PICC line was 
d/c'd prior to his discharge.
The patient started with increased stooling, and C diff A&B was 
sent. The cultures were negative x 5, however he was started on 
PO Vanco as his WBC remained elevated, and no other source was 
identified. A CMV viral load was sent which was positive at 909 
copies, he was started on a 3 week course of Valcyte. He also 
has a positive HSV screen from a lesion on his lip. The Valcyte 
will cover both. In addition, he had a stool for CMV sent, which 
was negative up to this time, but had not yet been finalized.
Approximately 2 weeks into the hospitalization, the patient 
developed new onset AFib.  He was chemically converted on 
Amiodarone and was started on a heparin drip. Due to the 
interaction between amiodarone, Prograf and Coumadin, the 
patient was started on half dose Coumadin on ___. Over the next 
2 days, his Hct was noted to fall from 27% to 17%. The 
anticoagulation was stopped and he received 3 units of pRBC's. 
Of note, his stool at this time was noted to be dark and guaiac 
positive. The heparin drip and coumadin were placed on hold. The 
amiodarone was discontinued and it was decided to rate control 
the patient which was well achieved with beta blockade. The 
coumadin was restarted at an even lower dose, as well, the 
heparin remained off and he was started on Lovenox injection, 
which he will be continuing at home short term.
Dr ___ a cystoscopy on ___ due to concern for 
fluid from the JP drain from initial surgery was found to have a 
creatinine of 22.9. He underwent cystoscopy, a 4.8 ___ x 10 
cm double-J stent was placed with the proximal coil in the 
collecting system and distal coil in the bladder. A Foley drain 
was left in place which should be left in place for two weeks. 
Patient to be seen in ___ clinic with Dr ___. A JP drain 
is also in place, removal will be following Foley removal by 
several days and will be determined by urology.
Patient was given a glucometer and will check blood sugars at 
home. Given signs and symptoms of low blood sugar and started on 
Glipizide per ___ recommendations.
Scripts were given to the patient for new medications which will 
be filled at patients home ___ 
at their free pharmacy as this has been his usual source for his 
medications. 
Dr ___ (pager ___, fax ___, his PCP 
___ be monitoring ___ and was contacted on ___ to verify 
this. ___ will draw and fax results of first two INRs and then 
they will be arranged as an outpatient.

Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ at ___ if you have 
temperature>101.5, chills, nausea or vomiting, worsening 
abdominal pain, vomiting blood or bloody/black bowel movements, 
redness/pus or  drainage around incision, or drains, cloudy foul 
smelling urine, or drain output stops or increases 
Empty the drain (JP) and foley (urine bag) when half full and 
record volume of outputs. Bring this record of drain/urine 
outputs to next appointment with Dr. ___ and INR will be drawn by the visiting nurse on ___ 
and ___. Results to be faxed to Dr ___ will be 
managing your anticoagulation
Check your blood sugar by fingerstick at least once daily. If 
you feel sweaty, clammy, confused or anxious, these can be signs 
of low blood sugar. Have some juice and then check your blood 
sugar. A low reading is less than 70
No Heavy lifting

History of Present Illness:
Briefly, this is a ___ year old woman with PPH schizophrenia,
medication nonadherent, living at ___, ___
obesity, HTN, who presented to the ___ with dyspnea and chest
pressure, received negative medical workup, and was placed on a
___ out of concern for decompensated psychosis.

History was limited in the ___ due to patient's thought blocking
and disorganization. She reported active AH and stated these 
were
not commanding in nature. She reported depressed mood but was
unable to describe this further, and denied changes to sleep,
appetite, energy, or motivation. She further denied VH, SI, HI,
and s/sx of mania.

Patient reported that one month ago, she had moved to ___ 
from
___, where her family lives. Shortly after arrival,
she was hospitalized for 12 days at ___. Per records from
this facility, patient participated in groups and had no
behavioral issues while at this facility. However, patient 
states
she was discharged with no scheduled aftercare planning, and was
unable to pick up her medication at the pharmacy.

In the ___, patient was calm and cooperative, did not require
physical or chemical restraints. She was restarted on her HTN
meds as well as her Lexapro 15mg QD and risperidone 1mg BID. She
took two doses of Lexapro as prescribed; however, she refused 
the
risperidone.

On interview today, patient is mildly disorganized but
conversant. She reports her mood as "okay." She corroborates 
much
of the above history, and elaborates: she moved to ___ to
attend college and hopefully become a ___. She believes in 
her
diagnosis of schizophrenia: states that at age ___ she was told 
she
would become schizophrenic, but her symptoms only began in ___.
She reports ongoing AH of two voices which comment on her
activities and are sometimes derogatory; however, they have
become "quieter" over the past several months and do not bother
her greatly. She reports that Lexapro helps with them "even
though it's an antidepressant, so it's not supposed do";
conversely she has not found antipsychotics helpful. She also
endorses paranoia but does not specify further, stating "I know
it's not real." She feels safe on the unit. However, she does 
not
want to be here: she has an NP at ___, and states "I just wanted
to get treatment for my shortness of breath."

Patient continues to deny CAH, VH, HI. Patient does report a
history of two suicide attempts (both by OD, "between ___ and
___. However,
she adamantly denies passive or active SI: "I want to move on
with my life." 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS
  
Psychiatric ROS as above. 

Medical ROS positive for: exertional chest pressure, dyspnea, 
and
fatigue, worsening for several years. Also reports occasional
urinary urge incontinence. Otherwise, a 10-point ROS was
negative, including: fever, headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea,
dysuria, back pain, focal weakness/numbness, saddle paresthesia.

Brief Hospital Course:
1. LEGAL & SAFETY: 

The patient signed a conditional voluntary agreement (Section 10 
& 11) with agreement to engage in medical work-up and allow for 
coordination of ___ with her outpatient medical and psychiatric 
providers. She was also placed on q15 minute checks status on 
admission and remained on that level of observation throughout 
while being unit restricted. She did not require physical or 
chemical restraints during this hospitalization. 

 

2. PSYCHIATRIC:

Upon admission, interview was limited due to active psychotic 
symptoms,
namely thought blocking and loosening of associations. Pt had 
vague reports of AH, paranoid thinking, and made contradictory 
statements around medication adherence. Mental status 
examination was notable for a disheveled woman in no acute 
distress, who was oddly related, with blunted and apathetic 
affect. Thought content was notable for auditory hallucinations, 
possible paranoia. Her thought process quickly derailed with 
loosening of associations, thought blocking, poverty of thought. 


The patient’s presentation was concerning for decompensation of 
her underlying chronic psychosis, likely either schizophrenia 
versus schizoaffective disorder, although she does not report 
significant affective symptoms at this time. This all occurring 
in the likely setting of medication nonadherence.

The patient was restarted on home medications, risperidone 1 mg 
BID and escitalopram 15 mg daily, which was increased to 20 mg 
daily. Patient was compliant with escitalopram and found it to 
be useful for her mood, however declined risperidone during 
hospitalization. She felt her SSRI offered her relief from 
symptoms, and felt antipsychotics had not been useful in the 
past. Patient's outpatient providers voiced that they are okay 
with this plan. Subsequent to her admission interview the 
patient was more organized. She did not demonstrate any positive 
symptoms of schizophrenia but was isolative to her bedroom, 
although cited physical respiratory impairment as the reason she 
did not leave her room frequently.

During hospitalization, patient continued to have symptoms of 
dyspnea and chest
pain on the unit. Patient's level of psychosis did not warrant 
the petitioning for treatment with antipsychotics over her 
objection as she is able to engage in treatment planning for her 
medical issues and is motivated to follow up with necessary 
testing, cardiac medications, and a discharge plan to a medical 
shelter. She has demonstrated good behavioral control on the 
unit, and collateral from outpatient providers did not raise a 
concern that the patient was unable to ___ for herself in the 
community due to her psychiatric illness. However, her dyspnea 
and obesity do appear to limit her mobility to the point where 
she has difficulty picking up medications and attending medical 
appointments. Therefore, would benefit from medical workup at 
this time.  

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
Currently there is no acute psychiatric concern. Psychiatric 
consult service does not need to be consulted at this time.
- Increased escitalopram to 20 mg daily 
- Patient declining risperidone, which her outpatient providers 
are comfortable with

___ have been requested. We will forward them to the internal 
medicine service when they arrive.

medical respite. Contact for admissions is ___

psychiatry follow-up at ___ for the Homeless with 
___, NP (___)

___

reported ongoing dyspnea and chest pain on exertion. Repeat EKG 
was unchanged from prior, CTA chest was negative, and CK and

were consistent with stable angina. Recommended obtaining

#Urinary incontinence: Patient has history consistent with urge

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.  

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon or your primary physician.

6. Please keep your wounds clean. You may shower starting five 
(5) days after surgery, but no tub baths or swimming for at 
least four (4) weeks. No dressing is needed if wound continues 
to be non-draining. Any stitches or staples that need to be 
removed will be taken out at your follow-up appointment 3 weeks 
after your surgery.

7. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks after surgery.

8. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory 
medications (NSAIDs such as celebrex, ibuprofen, advil, aleve, 
motrin, etc).

9. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your lovenox for three (3) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  After 
completing the lovenox, please take Aspirin 325mg  TWICE  daily 
for an additional three weeks.  ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

10. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
visit 3 weeks afetr surgery.

and wound checks. Antibiotic administration via ___.

12. ACTIVITY: NWB LLE. NO ROM. KNEE IMMOBILIZER AT ALL TIMES.

up appointment.  Ambulate frequently as tolerated.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ man with a history of smoking, bicuspid 
aortic valve with coarctation repaired in childhood, HIV (well 
controlled with CD4 948, HIV VL undetectable ___, recent 
history of splenic infarctions, lymphadenopathy, sclerotic bone 
lesions, weight loss, and chronic diarrhea with recent extensive 
workup for malignancy, who presented with a right MCA stroke 
syndrome, found to have narrowed, irregular MCAs, right worse 
than left. On exam he has left sided weakness, left facial 
droop, and left neglect, which is improving. He also has 
papilledema and was found to have a multifocal pneumonia at 
admission. He underwent an extensive workup to identify a 
unifying diagnosis that would explain his entire presentation.  
However the differential still remains broad and includes 
malignancy, angio-invasive infection, and vasculitis.

# Right MCA Stroke: 
He has multifocal areas of infarct on MRI that progressed on 
subsequent MRIs. Vessel imaging revealed right M1 stenosis as 
etiology. Given his normal lipid panel, splenic infarcts, and 
lack of HTN, DDx included infection, intravascular lymphoma, 
endocarditis, systemic hypercoagulability, and vasculitis as 
well as atherosclerosis as the etiology of vasculopathy. TTE and 
TEE showed an atrial septal defect with left-to-right flow, no 
clear vegetations, though there was a "bright mobile 
echodensity" on the aortic valve which is atypical in appearance 
for a vegetation. Lower extremity venous ultrasound was negative 
for DVT. He was started on aspirin for secondary prevention. 
Hematology was consulted for hypercoagulability workup. While 
his protein C and antithrombin levels were decreased, it was 
felt they were not sufficiently low to cause thrombosis.  He was 
treated with IV fluids and head of bed less than 30 degrees to 
optimize cerebral perfusion. ___ and OT were consulted and 
recommended acute rehab. Pt had witnessed overt aspiration of 
thin liquids but not thick liquids or solids. Speech language 
pathology was consulted and recommended nectar thick liquids to 
prevent further aspiration.

# Peripheral edema: Thought to be a combination of his 
malnutrition and fluid overload from resuscitation in setting of 
MCA stroke. He was started on TPN and diuresed with furosemide 
IV with improvement in his scrotal and leg edema. He was started 
on furosemide PO at discharge. 

# Failure to thrive/chronic diarrhea: Extensive workup has been 
unrevealing and the differential remains broad, including 
malignant, infectious, and vasculitic etiologies. ANCA was 
negative and abdominal CTA did not indicate vasculitis, and skin 
biopsy ruled out intravascular lymphoma. Lymph node biopsy was 
also nonspecific. Universal PCR of lymph node tissue is pending 
at discharge.  He has undergone extensive GI workup outpatient. 
GI team was consulted and stools studies were unrevealing. GI 
biopsies showed ileitis and diffuse inflammation, but was 
negative for Whipple's disease on PAS stain. Amyloidosis was 
considered, and ___ red stain of his GI biopsies is pending at 
discharge. His diarrhea was treated symptomatically with 
tincture of opium improvement. He had some abdominal bloating 
with tincture of opium so dose was decreased to BID:PRN 
diarrhea. He was started on TPN with improvement in his malaise. 
His chronic anemia also slowly worsened during this admission 
given phlebotomy and poor PO intake. He was transfused 1 unit 
pRBC prior to discharge for Hgb of 7.8 (down from ___ at 
admission.
 
# Lymphadenopathy: 
He has diffuse lymphadenoapthy seen on CT scans and thyroid 
ultrasound. He was seen by surgical oncology and underwent a 
right supraclavicular lymph node biopsy. Pathology was benign 
and showed a nonspecific reactive process. SPEP/UPEP was 
negative for monoclonal gammopathy. POEMS syndrome was initially 
proposed as a possible unifying diagnosis, however he did not 
meet criteria for this. His EBV PCR was positive for viremia at 
a level of 6353, however ID was consulted and felt this was due 
to reactivation in the setting of his underlying illness and was 
not the primary cause of his overall presentation.

# Papilledema: 
Papilledema was noted on dilated neurology admission exam. He 
had no pleocytosis on LP and no meningeal enhancement on MRI, 
ruling out. His opening pressure on lumbar puncture was 19. 
Given temporal lobe enhancement, was treated with acyclovir 
empirically pending his HSV PCR results, with pre and post 
hydration to protect his kidneys. Ophthalmology was consulted 
and confirmed papilledema on dilated exam. He will need 
outpatient followup. 

# Community Acquired Pneumonia: 
CXR on admission showed a multifocal PNA (new from ___ CXR) 
consistent with an atypical or viral process. CT chest was 
suspicious for LIP (lymphoid interstitial pneumonia), however 
pulmonology did not feel biopsy was indicated given stability of 
his respiratory status. He was treated with CTX/azithromycin for 
community acquired pneumonia and completed a 7-day course. He 
had a witnessed aspiration event during his lymph node biopsy 
and during evaluation by Speech Language Pathology. He was 
briefly febrile but recovered quickly, so fever was attributed 
to aspiration pneumonitis. He was placed on a diet of nectar 
thick liquids to prevent further aspiration.

# HIV: 
Well controlled on anti-retroviral medication. Most recent CD4 
948, HIV VL undetectable ___. Has never had AIDS. Continued 
his home Atripla (non-formulary so substituted with efavirenz 
600 daily and emtricitabine-tenofovir 200/300 daily). Rechecked 
his viral load which was undetectable.

# Hypothyroidism: 
Has diffuse thyroiditis on ultrasound and elevated anti-TPO 
antibodies consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis. He had 
reactions to levothyroxine in the past so was untreated. 
Endocrine was consulted and felt the allergy may have been to 
the dye in the pills. He was started in levothyroxine with a 
formulation without dyes and tolerated the trial well without 
rash or other complications. His dose was titrated accordingly 
and he will follow up in ___ clinic for further 
titration.

Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Discharge Instructions

What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
•You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
•Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
•Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!

2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on:
•Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
•Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated

3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
•You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
•Eat small frequent meals
•It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
•To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
•No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications
•Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

•You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
•You should gradually increase your activity
•You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
•Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away!
•No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
•You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry
•Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed
•Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
•Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, 
unless otherwise directed 
•Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for 
staple/suture removal

What to report to office:
•Redness that extends away from your incision
•A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication
•A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg
•Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
•Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old female, 11 weeks pregnant, who 
presented to the hospital  with epigastric pain, nausea and 
vomiting.  Upon admission, the patient was made NPO, given 
intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging.  Her blood work 
showed elevated liver enzymes.  She underwent an ultra-sound of 
the liver and gallbladder and an MRI which showed sludge in the 
gallbladder. During her hospitalization, the OB-GYN service 
monitored the patient and the fetal heart rate.

The patient was taken to the operating room on HD #2 where she 
underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  The operative course 
was stable.  There was bile spillage upon entering the 
gallbladder which was suctioned. The patient was extubated after 
the procedure and monitored in the recovery room.

Her post-operative course was stable.  After recovering from 
anesthesia, the patient was started on a regular diet.  She was 
voiding without difficulty.  She reported nausea after 
administration  of oxycodone and for this reason was given an 
anti-emetic and started on diluadid.  The patient did not 
experience any further nausea.  Her vital signs remained stable 
and she was voiding without difficulty.  The patient was 
discharged  home on the operative date.  A follow-up appointment 
was made with the acute care service.  She was also instructed 
to follow-up with her OB/GYN providers.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
choledocholithiasis 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with right upper quadrant 
pain, nausea and vomitting.  You underwent an ultrasound of the 
gallbladder which showed sludge.  You were taken to the 
operating room where you had your gallbladder removed.  You are 
recovering from the surgery and you are preparing for discharge 
home with the following instructions:

You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder 
removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and 
are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the 
following instructions.
Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the 
appointment listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You 
might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You 
might feel somewhat depressed.
You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay).
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to the pre-operative setting were the 
rationale, risks, and benefits of the procedure were reviewed 
and consents were confirmed and signed. He underwent cystoscopy 
and right laparoscopic radical nephrectomy on ___ with Dr. 
___. Please see operative report for full details. He was 
brought to the PACU with foley catheter in place draining clear 
yellow urine. Post-operatively in the PACU he was found to be 
hypotensive with mildly low urine output so was transferred to 
the ICU for further monitoring and care. He was started on 
vasopressor support to maintain his blood pressure on ___. 
Given concern for post-operative acute blood loss anemia, his 
subcutaneous heparin and home dose aspirin were held. He was 
evaluated by both transplant nephrology and transplant surgery 
given his past medical history. On POD#1 he was transfused 
packed red blood cells (4 units total) with an adequate 
response. He was weaned off vasopressors by POD#2. By POD#3, his 
hematocrit had stabilized and he received furosemide for 
diuresis given his volume overload. On exam he had a maturing 
ecchymotic area over his right lower quadrant incision that 
persisted throughout the admission. He was transferred out of 
the ICU to the medical surgical floor where his hematocrit 
remained stable on serial checks. His foley catheter was removed 
on POD#4 and he was able to void without difficulty. His diet 
was slowly advanced as he regained bowel function and he was 
able to tolerate a regular diet prior to discharge. The 
transplant/nephrology service evaluated him and recommended his 
immunosuppression doses and to hold his midodrine given his 
stable/high blood pressures in his left arm (dysynchrony between 
upper extremity blood pressures given AV fistula). His 
creatinine had normalized at this time (developed ___ secondary 
to hypovolemic shock in the ICU). On POD#5 and 6 he was given IV 
furosemide for diuresis for his clinical hypervolemia. Just 
prior to discharge his creatinine was normal, his hematocrit was 
stable, he was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating without 
difficulty, voiding without difficulty, his pain was controlled, 
he was on a stable immunosuppression regimen, and he had no new 
complaints.

Discharge Instructions:
-Please also refer to the provided “handout” that details 
instructions and expectations for your post-operative phase as 
made available by your urologist. 

***please keep a log of narcotics (pain pill) used over the week 
and return the log sheet at your follow up appointment. Remember 
to also bring the narcotic prescription bottle WITH YOU for your 
follow up appointment.

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications except as noted. 
ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication changes 
and your post-operative course with your primary care doctor.

-___ reduce the strain/pressure on your abdomen and incision 
sites; remember to “log roll” onto your side and then use your 
hands to push yourself upright while taking advantage of the 
momentum of putting your legs/feet to the ground.

--There may be bandage strips called “steristrips” which have 
been applied to reinforce wound closure.  Allow these bandage 
strips to fall off on their own over time but PLEASE REMOVE ANY 
REMAINING GAUZE DRESSINGS WITHIN 2 DAYS OF DISCHARGE. You may 
get the steristrips wet.

-UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED; AVOID aspirin or aspirin containing 
products and supplements that may have “blood-thinning” effects 
(like Fish Oil, Vitamin E, etc.).  This will be noted in your 
medication reconciliation. 

IF PRESCRIBED (see the MEDICATION RECONCILIATION):
-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control.  

For pain control, try TYLENOL (acetaminophen) FIRST, then 
ibuprofen, and then take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-Call your Urologist's office to schedule/confirm your follow-up 
appointment in 4 weeks AND if you have any questions.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised. Light household chores/activity and leisurely 
walking/activity is OK and should be continued. Do NOT be a 
“couch potato”

-Tylenol should be your first-line pain medication. A narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain ___.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is THREE to FOUR grams 
from ALL sources

•AVOID lifting/pushing/pulling items heavier than 10 pounds (or 
3 kilos; about a gallon of milk) or participate in high 
intensity physical activity (which includes intercourse) until 
you are cleared by your Urologist in follow-up.

-No DRIVING for THREE WEEKS or until you are cleared by your 
Urologist

-You may shower normally but do NOT immerse your incisions or 
bathe

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery

-You may be given “prescriptions” for a stool softener and/or a 
gentle laxative. These are  over-the-counter medications that 
may be “health care spending account reimbursable.” 

-Colace (docusate sodium) may have been prescribed to avoid 
post-surgical constipation or constipation related to use of 
narcotic pain medications. Discontinue if loose stool or 
diarrhea develops. Colace is a stool-softener, NOT a laxative.

-Senokot (or any gentle laxative) may have been prescribed to 
further minimize your risk of constipation. 

-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest emergency room.

DIET

Resume your regular home diet (regular, diabetic/consistent 
carbohydrate, heart healthful, etc.) and remember to drink 
plenty of fluids to keep hydrated and to reduce the risk of 
constipation.  Continue with the stool softener as recommended 
to minimize the risk of constipation, especially while using the 
narcotics.

Brief Hospital Course:
This ___ year-old boy with likely nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy 
(see below), followed by phenytoin treatment started at ___ 
ED with subsequent hypersensitivity reaction. 

Rash
  Mr ___ was seen by dermatology and allergy and thought to 
be likely due to hypersensitivity to dilantin.  DRESS is 
fulfilled given eosinophilia, new medication, systemic symptoms. 
Actually very characteristic of phenytoin and carbemazapine 
hypersensitivity. Likely due to former given had been taken for 
near a month and the latter only taken once. Nonetheless, both 
agents should now be avoided. We It is likely that these two 
signs are related, given the onset of each. This is consistent 
with phenytoin hypersensitivity and infectious etiologies. 
Phenytoin hypersensitivities can also cause blood dyscrasias, 
lymphadenopathy, hepatitic liver enzymes, eosinophilia. This is 
quite well described (See abstract below). Phenytoin 
hypersensitivity actually accounts for all manifestations and 
would be the most elegant explanation. Infectious disease can 
also be considered, particularly including EBV, CMV. 
Hematological processes are also possible. Skin biopsy may be of 
assistance. 
  Pathology report from skin biopsy, not finalized, but 
available: "Interface dermatitis with mild epidermal spongiosis, 
focal erythrocyte extravasation, and superficial to mid dermal 
perivascular lymphohistiocytic inflammation with scattered 
eosinophils (see note)."
  He was observed in the MICU for 24 hours.  He was started on 
solumedrol 1 mg/kg per day (50 mg/day, clobetasol ointment to 
body, hydrocortisone to face, aquophor and vaseline to lips.  He 
was given benadryl for the itching and a panel of labs were sent 
including HIV, HepC, EBV, Lyme titers, and a punch biopsy was 
sent by dermatology.  TFTs on ___ were normal. Laboratory 
findings were essentially only consistent with DRESS/Dilantin 
hypersensitivity. He was transferred to the floor where steroids 
were increase to 125 mg IV Solumedrol daily for four days, 
prednisone taper was then commenced at 60 mg with a plan to 
taper by 10 mg every 4 days, then 5mg for four days. He was also 
given famotidine and IV Benadryl on the floor. Rash and other 
symptoms clear quickly. 
   
Fevers
  Had two to three days of fevers in conjunction with the rash, 
however he was afebrile in the MICU for his ___ 24 hours.  Blood 
and urine cultures were sent, CXR was done which was 
unremarkable.  As above, a number of labs were sent to determine 
possible infective causes.  He was consented to HIV which was 
also sent and found to be negative. He returned an equivocal 
result for HBV shell antibody. Equivocal Lyme was found in ___ 
___, but both here were negative. 

Body aches / headache
  Likely related to flu-like syndrome associated with reaction, 
as part of DRESS. Body aches improved over MICU course and with 
ibuprofen as needed. Infectious etiologies effectively excluded. 

  
Elevated LFTs
  No history liver disease or alcohol abuse. Intermediate levels 
consistent with viremia, but excluded on testing. Again part of 
this DRESS. These will need to be followed closely for 
resolution.
  
Anemia
  Unclear etiology, iron studies not consistent necessarily with 
iron deficiency anemia.  In setting of acute illness, his CBCs 
were followed. Hemolysis was possible earlier in his 
presentation. 
  
Abdominal Pain
  Appeared on first day of hospitalisation and was improved by 
steroids. Was not helped by Maalox (initially though likely ___ 
steroids with reflux and gastritis). Given normal KUB and AUS, 
we now think that this likely represented para-aortic and 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy, perhaps mesenteric adenopathy. 
This resolved with other features during steroid treatement. He 
was briefly given opioids, but later required no pain 
medications. 

'Seizures'
  Differential includes REM sleep behavior disorder, night 
terrors, restless legs symdrome with periodic limb movements and 
epilepsies - most likely of which is familial nocturnal frontal 
lobe epilepsy. Parasomnias are very unlikely based on family 
history and history of the present illness. The description was 
classic for nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy. The age of onset 
for NFLE is correct, but this may well be non-familial, or we 
may not understand his pedigree or relatives' history well (also 
not completely penetrant or noticed). REM sleep behavior 
disorder not consistent with history (no narcoleptic symptoms). 
No earlier onset PD. First line is typically carbemazepine, but 
this is now contraindicated. Given the natural history of this 
disorder, treatment may not be necessary (typically resolves 
with aging). He will see Neurology as an outpatient. He was not 
started on treatment.

Related Abstract:

___. Phenytoin Hypersensitivity - 38 Cases. NEUROLOGY 
___.

To determine the frequency and severity of hypersensitivity 
reactions to phenytoin, we reviewed 38 cases of proven 
reactions. Patients were included only if no other drugs, 
including other anticonvulsants, were in use at the time of the 
reaction. Rashes were most frequent, followed by fever, 
lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, abnormal liver function tests, 
blood dyscrasias, serum sickness, renal failure, and 
polymyositis. The pseudolymphoma syndrome (fever, rash, and 
lymphadenopathy) occurred in nine patients. ___ of the 
38 reactions occurred within 2 months of the start of therapy. 
Phenytoin sensitivity accounted for 467 inpatient days during 
the ___ years of study. Early recognition of phenytoin reactions, 
prompt drug withdrawal, and appropriate therapeutic measures are 
necessary to prevent serious morbidity from phenvtoin 
hypersensitivity.

Discharge Instructions:
You came to the hosptial with a rash and fever. This along with 
your history of taking phenytoin (Dilantin) and your laboratory 
abnormalities were characterstic of phenytoin hypersensitivity 
syndrome. You should never take phenytoin or carbemazepine in 
the furture.

# CONTACT DERMATITIS:
Three common conditions for the presentation of crusting scaly 
plaques with pruritus, excoriations, and attendant edema with 
erythema and warmth include atopic dermatitis, contact 
dermatitis, and infectious cellulitis.  An atopic picture is 
consistent with his history of itchiness and cracking skin 
lesions prior to any exposure to possible skin irritants.  
Moreover, atopic dermatitis can be exacerbated by exposure to 
chemical irritants, which can further dry out the skin and lead 
to itchiness and scratching-induced excoriations.

The history of exposure to an irritant points in the diagnostic 
direction of contact dermatitis.  But the fact that his symptoms 
predated the exposure by days-to-weeks argues against CD.  
Further, the lack of leukocytosis and systemic symptoms in the 
presence of pruritus suggest contact dermatitis or atopic 
dermatitis vs. infectious cellulitis.  However, it is certainly 
possible that a secondary infection could occur due to a 
disrupted skin barrier due to primary dermatitis.  Another 
infectious etiological possibility could include a fungal 
infection (such as tinea versicolor from Malassezia), especially 
considering the pathcy hypo-to-hyperpigmentation distribution in 
the abdomen worsened with sweating.

Other inflammatory or immune processes could be to blame, such 
as psoriasis.  However, psoriasis is unlikely given the lack of 
silver plaques on an erythematous base and the lack of extensor 
surface involvement. Of course, several of these processes could 
be operating concurrently. 

We also considered underlying systemic conditions such as DM, 
HIV and Hep C that might predispose him to immunodeficiency 
leading to susceptibility to fungal or scabies infection over a 
wider skin surface.  However, this was unlikely in the context 
of his negative HIV result and the negative ___ prep looking for 
fungal involvement as well as the negative scabies prep, though 
these tests do not definitively rule out tinea pedis or scabies. 
 Overall, our initial clinical interpretation prior to punch 
biopsy results was that this could be a combination of atopic 
and contact dermatitis.  One uncommon cause discussed was 
necrotizing acral erythema, which is a hyperkeratotic 
erythematous eruption resembling psoriasis typically seen in 
patients with hepatitis C infection. Ultimately, the prelim 
pathological determination per derm was that this is contact 
dermatitis on ___.

We treated the pt initially with topical corticosteroid 
(hydrocortisone 1%) and controlled pruritus with 1G 
antihistamine (diphenhydramine 25 mg q6h). We consulted 
dermatology in the AM on ___ who recommended switching to 
clobetasol (0.05% ointment BID), which was begun in the ___ on 
___.  He was discharged on the clobetasol ointment, which 
should be applied to the affected areas on the leg and trunk for 
a maximum of 2 weeks duration.  The antihistamine can be taken 
as needed for any residual itching.

Brief Hospital Course:
MS. ___ is a ___ woman with postmenopausal bleeding 
and a thickened endometrium seen on imaging studies, now s/p 
laparoscopy converted to an exploratory laparotomy, total 
abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, pelvic 
washings, proctosigmoidoscopy, and cystoscopy (see operative 
note for details).

Her post-operative course has been complicated by the following 
issues:

*) Cardiac: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation.  
On POD#1 she experienced an episode of atrial fibrillation.  She 
converted to normal sinus rhythm with 5mg IV Lopressor.  
Cardiology was curb sided and recommended started PO Lopressor 
25mg TID.  On POD#3, patient's Coumadin was re-started. On 
POD#7, her Coumadin was stopped secondary to a prolonged ileus 
and concern for rising INRs. On POD#7, the patient complained of 
chest pain.  An EKG, reviewed by cardiology, revealed no acute 
changes.  Cardiac enzymes were negative x 3. Her chest 
discomfort was treated with Protonix IV.  On POD#9 she had 
approximately ___ beats of VTach on telemetry with spontaneous 
resolution to normal sinus rhythm.  Electrolytes were obtained 
and repleted, EKG demonstrated normal sinus rhythm, and cardiac 
enzymes were negative x1.  Medicine was consulted and per their 
recommendations, her Coumadin was restarted on POD#11 at 3mg 
qhs. She remained on telemetry for the remainder of her 
hospitalization with no additional episodes.

*) GI:  The patient developed a post-operative ileus on POD#4.  
She initially presented with abdominal distention and nausea.  
An abdominal x-ray demonstrated multiple dilated loops of bowel 
and air fluid levels.  She remained NPO with IV fluids until POD 
#7, at which time her diet was slowly advanced.  Her 
electrolytes were checked daily and repleted accordingly.  She 
was able to tolerate a regular diet on her day of discharge 
without difficulty.   Additionally, on POD#10, the patient 
developed watery diarrhea.  C.diff culture was negative.  Her 
watery diarrhea resolved by her day of discharge. 

*) GU:  Intra-operatively, it was noted that the patient 
underwent an extensive lysis of adhesions around the bladder.  
Post-operatively, she failed two voiding trials, therefore her 
foley was left in place and the patient was placed on Macrobid 
for UTI prophylaxis.  She was discharged home with a Foley 
catheter in place.  She will follow up in ___ 
to have her Foley removed.

*) HTN: The patient's blood pressure remained within normal 
limits throughout her hospitalization.  She remained on her home 
medications.

*)Asthma: The patient's asthma remained well controlled 
throughout her hospitaliztion.  She remained on her home 
medications.

The patient's pain remained well controlled throughout her 
hospitalization.  She was able to tolerate a regular diet and 
ambulate without difficulty on her day of discharge.  

The patient was discharged home on POD#13 in stable condition.

Albuterol, clonazepam, diltiazem, Fiorinal, lisinopril, Micro-K, 
Protonix, warfarin, Azmacort.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with recurrent follicular cell lymphoma who 
presents from for scheduled EPOCH chemotherapy.
.  
# Follicular Cell Lymphoma. Prior to starting her chemotherapy 
with EPOCH, a baseline echocardiogram was attained which showed 
that she had EF of 70%.  On day #1 she received Etoposide, 
doxorubisin, vincristine, and prednisone. On Day #5 she received 
cyclophorphamide and prednisone.  She tollerated this 
chemotherapy wothout any symptoms or side effects.  Tumor lysis 
labs were monitored and showed no evidence of tumor lysis.  She 
did not require any blood or platelet transfusions or have any 
fevers.  On day #6 she was discharged with instructions to start 
taking Neupogen in 2 days and continue neupogen until her clinic 
visit in 5 days.  At that time labs will be drawn and the 
decision can be made whether or not she should continue taking 
this medication..  
.  
# Hematuria. At admission, the pt denied seeing any blood in her 
urine since the ifosphamide toxicity.  On UA there was a large 
amount blood and 479 RBCs and 11 WBCs. A repeat UA showed less 
blood and only a few WBCs, no ___ or ___.  Repeat UA prior 
to discharge showed only a small amount of blood and 19 RBCs 
with < 1 WBC.
.  
# Hypertension:  The patient was continued on her home dose of 
atenolol, but her lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide were held.  
She has not restarted those medications since her renal toxicity 
from the iphosphamide. She was noted to have blood pressures in 
the 150's systolic.  She will likely need to be restarted on her 
diuretics as an outpatient.
.  
# Weight gain:  The pt's weight was 132 on admission and 
steadily increased to 156 over her relatively short admission.  
It was thought that the weight gain was from the aggressive 
hydration that she was receiving with chemotherapy.  However, 
she did not show any clinical signs of overhydration - no edema, 
rhales, or elevated JVP were noted.  She was given lasix to try 
to even out her intake and output and she responded somewhat to 
it, but but she still remained 1 to 2 liters positive each day 
which likely contributed to her weight gain.  She was 
assymptomatic at discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Kidney Transplant
Please call the transplant clinic at ___ for fever > 
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, inability 
to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of skin or 
eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, drainage or 
bleeding, dizziness or weakness, glucoses consistently over 200, 
decreased urine output or dark, cloudy urine, swelling of 
abdomen or ankles,  or any other concerning symptoms.

Continue hemodialysis on ___ schedule at your 
outpatient HD unit in ___. You are scheduled for a kidney 
transplant biopsy on ___ (see appointment section). DO 
NOT TAKE COUMADIN, ASPIRIN or Non-Steroidal medications

Your next lab draw will be on ___ then labwork twice 
weekly as arranged by the transplant clinic, with results to the 
transplant clinic (Fax ___ . CBC, Chem 10, AST, T 
Bili, Trough Tacro level, Urinalysis. 

**On the days you have your labs drawn, do not take your 
Tacrolimus until your labs are drawn. Bring your Tacrolimus with 
you so you may take your medication as soon as your labwork has 
been drawn.

Follow your medication card, keep it updated with any dosage 
changes, and always bring your card with you to any clinic or 
hospital visits.

You may shower with soap and water, rinse, pat dry. Do not apply 
lotions or powder near the incision. You may leave the incision 
open to the air. The staples will be removed approximately 3 
weeks following your transplant.

No tub baths or swimming
No driving if taking narcotic pain medications

Avoid direct sun exposure. Wear protective clothing and a hat, 
and always wear sunscreen with SPF 30 or higher when you go 
outdoors.

Drink enough fluids to keep your urine light in color. Your 
appetite will return with time. Eat small frequent meals, and 
you may supplement with things like carnation instant breakfast 
or Ensure

Do not increase, decrease, stop or start medications without 
consultation with the transplant clinic at ___. There 
are significant drug interactions with anti-rejection 
medications which must be considered in medication management 
following transplant

Refer to the transplant binder. 
There is always someone on call at the transplant clinic with 
any questions that may arise

Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain and 
had recently had an abnormal stress test. 

What was done while I was in the hospital?
==========================================
- You had blood work which showed you were not having a heart 
attack; however, you had a heart catheterization which showed 
blockage of one of the arteries of your heart. A stent was 
placed to open the blockage. Another narrow area was opened up 
with a balloon.
- You were started on two new medications: "ticagrelor" for 
keeping your arteries open (this replaced your old medication, 
clopidogrel) and "lisinopril" 

What should I do now that I am going home?
========================================== 
*Please take all of your medicines as prescribed. Do not forget 
to take the aspirin daily or the ticagrelor twice per day, 
because missing these medicines can cause your stents to close. 
*Do not take more than 81 mg ASA per day. If you have pain, you 
can take acetaminophen aka Tyelenol. Do not take NSAIDs (Aleve, 
Advil, Motrin, Ibuprofen, etc.). If you have questions, please 
call your doctor. 
*Continue to go to cardiac rehab
*Follow-up with your PCP (___) and Dr. ___ 
appointment is being scheduled for you). 

It was a pleasure participating in your care,
-Your ___ Team

Brief Hospital Course:
Confusion/hallucinations: 
Patient presented following episode of confusion at home in 
which she set her kitchen on fire. Her family feels that 
although she is sometimes confused, they were unaware that she 
was capable of setting the kitchen on fire. No evidence of 
intracranial process on admission head CT. Reversible causes of 
mental status changes such as urinary tract infection, 
hypothyroidism, syphilis, B12 deficiency, and folate deficiency 
were all ruled-out with appropriate testing. SW spoke with the 
family and reinforced the need for closer supervision of the 
patient vs. placement in nursing facility. Family was insistent 
on the patient returning home and assured that they would 
implement safety measures at home, such as disconnecting the 
stove. ___ was set up to have a home safety evaluation and 
occupational therapy to assess for further care needs at home. 
Additionally, patient was scheduled for memory clinic assessment 
to further define and assess degree of severity of her apparent 
dementia.

Thrombocytopenia: 
Unclear if this is new or is baseline for the patient, however 
has been stable during this admission. There was no concern for 
acute bleeding. Differential diagnosis includes disorders of 
decreased platelet production from viral infections, vitamin 
deficiencies, myelodysplastic syndrome. Patient has follow-up 
with her primary care physician later this week, during which 
this issue should be further addressed.

Weight Loss:
Patient reports a 30 lb weight loss with no clear localizing 
symptoms although she is a difficult historian. CXR per report 
shows apical scarring which raises suspicion for prior 
tuberculosis infection, however pt is asymptomatic, therefore 
will hold off on PPD for now. TSH WNL. She does have leukopenia 
and thrombocytopenia and some atypical lymphs on blood smear 
which raises question for hematologic malignancy, which should 
be addressed as outpatient. Unlikely to have HIV risk factors. 
She does not have evidence of advance cardiac or pulmonary 
disease. 
  
Hypertension: 
Patient remained stable with no concerning drops or rises in 
blood pressure while in the hospital. We continued her on 
lisinopril 40 mg daily, hydrochlororthiazide 12.5 mg daily, and 
dosed her metroprolol as metoprolol tartrate 100 mg BID.
 
Fall in hospital: 
Patient had unwitnessed mechanical fall while attempting to get 
up from chair. Head CT, hip films, and left leg film were 
negative after the fall. Patient was provided with a walker 
prior to discharge, per ___ recommendations.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year-old woman with herpetic neuralgia since 
diagnosis of V1-V2 shingles (s/p 7 days valacyclovir treatment 
and prednisone taper), started on oxcarbazepine on ___ with 
dose uptitration over the week due to severe pain symptoms. She 
presented from clinic with hyponatremia likely ___ 
oxcarbazepine. 

ACUTE ISSUES:
===============
#Hypoosmolar Hyponatremia 
Urine electrolytes were consistent with SIADH, likely secondary 
to oxcarbazepine up-titration. The oxcarbazepine was stopped. 
She was kept on a fluid restriction, and serum sodium slowly 
corrected to within normal limits. She was given intermittent 
D5W blouse to prevent overly rapid correction. TSH and AM 
cortisol were within normal limits. 
Discharge sodium: 138, stable for > 36 hours

#Trigeminal neuralgia v. subacute VZV
Patient developed facial pain following left V1, V2 distribution 
of zoster opthalmicus. This was diagnosed by her outpatient 
neurologist as trigeminal neuralgia. Given the time frame of 
about 4 weeks after VZV, subacute VZV is also on the 
differential diagnosis. Her oxcarbazepine was stopped. Pain 
service was consulted, and per their recommendations, she was 
started on Baclofen 5mg TID and her Gabapentin was increased to 
600mg TID.  

#Toxic Metabolic Encephalopathy
Patient presented with slow thought and unsteady gait, likely 
secondary to hyponatremia. During admission, she remained fully 
oriented and alert. However, per her husband, she continued to 
have slow speech and thought process even after her sodium had 
corrected to within normal limits. This may have been secondary 
to up-titrating gabapentin. She also expressed anxiety about 
unpredictable pain and the effect they might have on her work, 
so depressed mood in the setting of new diagnosis and 
unpredictable pain may also contribute to slowed thinking. She 
was evaluated by neurology who noted that these memory problems 
have been ongoing for at least a year. She did well on all 
neurocognitive testing, so there was low concern for 
neurodegenerative disease. They felt she was safe for outpatient 
neurology follow-up.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
========================
 Medications: 
[] Oxcarbazepine was discontinued.
[] Gabapentin was up-titrated to 600mg TID.
[] Please monitor mental status, and consider down-titrating or 
stopping gabapentin if concern for ongoing altered mental 
status.
[] Baclofen 5mg TID was started. Consider uptitrating as 
appropriate.
[] TCAs were avoided for now given this episode of hyponatremia, 
however if above neuropathic agents are optimized in dosing and 
do not provide adequate benefit, could consider adding Cymbalta.
[] topical Lidocaine started
[] Please assess for improvement in episodes of pain, and 
whether medications can be tapered off

given patient's concerns about her pain affecting her job.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old woman with hx of asplenia (traumatic), migraines now 
presents to the ED after 3 days of low grade fever, myalgias, 
fatigue and local pain and redness at a site of recent 
immunization injection into L deltoid, HA and increased neck 
stiffness with hyponatremia and leukocytosis.  
.
# Leukocytosis, Hypotension with constellation of symptoms: The 
patient's myalgias, arthralgias and low grade fevers were 
thought to be likely due to an inflammatory reaction to 
receiving vaccinations. Her leukocytosis was slightly 
incongruent was this and was thought to be related to 
cellulitis. Of note, although the patient presented with low 
blood pressures, she was always stable and even after she was 
afebrile had systolics in the ___ and low 100s. LP was done out 
of concern for neck pain with fevers but was negative. C.diff 
was negative and Blood Cultures are negative to date on 
discharge (final pending.) Given concern for infection in the 
setting of asplenia, she was initially treated with Vancomycin, 
Zosyn and Clindamycin per ID recommendations. However, as her 
fever improved, her antibiotics regimen was narrowed to 
Vancomycin; she was discharged on 10 days of IV Vancomycin, with 
PICC for cellulitis (see below.) Her pain was treated with 
Tylenol, Ibuprofen and Ultram. 
.
# L arm cellulitis: Ms. ___ had extensive R arm cellulitis that 
spread outside of previously marked borders over her first day 
of stay but improved on Vanc/Zosyn/Clindamycin, and continued to 
improve when she was narrowed to Vanc. The nidus of infection 
was thought to be her vaccination. Extensive imaging was done 
(see result section) to look for gas or abscess, but was all 
negative. The cellulitis was thought to be secondary to seeding 
at the vaccination site. As described above, she was initially 
treated with Vanc, Zosyn, Clinda but this was narrowed to Vanc 
alone for discharge.   
.  
# Hyponatriemia: The patient was initially hyponatremic in the 
setting of hypovolemia; this resolved with fluid repletion. 
.  
# Transaminitis: The patient had a mild transaminitis in the 
setting of some mild epigastric pain. A RUQ U/S was negative. 
These elevated markers were thought to be due to muscle 
inflammation secondary to her cellulitis; they downtrended prior 
to discharge.

 He was briefly started on hypertonic therapy, but this was

transitioned to comfort measures.  He remained spontaneously 
hypotensive, not breathing above the vent.  On ___ at 1643,

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ presented to the ___ ED with ~36 hours of acute 
onset bilateral lower extremity pain and feet numbness, left 
worse than right, associated with loss of pulses and signals. 
Exam was worrisome for non-palpable femoral pulses, weak
popliteal signals, and absent distal signals as well as 
moderately decreased sensorimotor function on the left. Clinical 
picture was consistent with acute limb ischemia from what 
imaging shows to be complete bilateral proximal artery 
occlusions with reconstitution in the profunda. Symptoms 
slightly improved on
systemic anticoagulation but required immediate surgical 
intervention to prevent limb loss.

She was taken to the operating room on ___ for a bilat 
thrombectomy, angio, R EIA stent, L CIA/EIA stent. Her 
intraoperative course was remarkable for formation of fresh 
thrombi intra-operatively, that could be evacuated. Further, her 
EBL was 1200 and she received IVF 6L and 3u pRBC. For full 
details, please see the operative report.  She was transferred 
to the ICU post-op intubated. She was extubated on POD#1 without 
issues. Postoperatively, she developed HIT in response to the 
heparin she had received perioperatively. Her heparin gtt was 
stopped and an argatroban gtt was ordered. Her PF4 Heparin 
Antibodies and SRA assay were positive, confirming HIT. 
Hematology was consulted and recommended either Coumadin for 
life or dual anti-platelet therapy. Due to her anaphylactic 
reaction to Plavix, she will either have to undergo Plavix 
desensitization in the ICU, or can test Ticagrelor, which should 
not have cross- reactivity (but case reports of cross- 
reactivity exist). 

She was transferred to the VICU on ___. She developed a 
temperature of ___ on ___ and was started on a short 
course of Bactrim. Bactrim was stopped on ___, as she was 
no longer febrile and there were no other signs of erythema or 
infection. Bilateral JP drains were pulled on ___. The left 
drain incision had serous output, and 3 stitches were placed on 
___. However, the incision continued to have serous output 
(~200cc/d). 

On POD#3, she was 5kg up from her baseline weight. Due to low 
blood pressure (90s/60s), she was not diuresed with Lasix until 
POD#5. She responded well.

On ___, her platelet count was >150, so she was started on 
2.5mg of Coumadin.

 Post-operatively, she did well without significant incisional 
swelling and no evidence of hemodynamic instability. She 
experienced afib with RVE, refractory to rate control 
medications, and was started on amiodarone drip. THis was 
transitioned to PO amiodarone over time. She was seen by 
cardiology, who recommended starting her on Coumadin for her new 
diagnosis of refractory afib. She will be discharged home on 
Coumadin with close vascular surgery and cardiology follow up. 
She will have ___ services for close monitoring of INR. At the 
time of discharge, she was doing well, afebrile with stable 
vital signs. She was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding without assistance, and her pain was well controlled on 
oral medications. She was deemed ready for discharge, and was 
given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  You were admitted to the hospital after surgery 
on your leg.   This surgery was done to improve blood flow to 
your leg. You tolerated the procedure well and are now ready to 
be discharged from the hospital.   Please follow the 
recommendations below to ensure a speedy and uneventful 
recovery.

Vascular Leg Surgery Discharge Instructions

What to except:

•It is normal feel tired for ___ weeks after your surgery
•It is normal to have leg swelling.  Keep your leg elevated as 
much as possible.  This will decrease the swelling. 
•Your leg will feel tired and sore.   This usually passes 
within a few weeks.
•Your incision will be sore, slightly raised, and pink.  Any 
drainage should decrease or stop with in the first 2 weeks. 
•If you are home, you will likely receive a visit from a 
Visiting Nurse ___.  Members of your health care team will 
discuss this with you before you go home.   

Medications:
•Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

•It is very important that you take Aspirin every day!  You 
should never stop this medication before checking with your 
surgeon

Pain Management:
•It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following surgery.  
This pain is often described as “soreness”. 
•You may take Tylenol (acetaminophen ) as needed for pain.   
You will also receive a prescription for stronger pain medicine, 
 if the Tylenol doesn’t work, take prescription medicine. 
•Narcotic pain medication can be very constipating, please also 
take a stool softner such as Colace.   If constipation becomes a 
problem, your pharmacist can suggest additional over the counter 
medications. 
•Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets to severe. 
•Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 


Activity:
•Do not drive until your surgeon says it is okay.  In general, 
driving is not allowed until
-the staples in your leg have been taken out
-your leg feels strong
-you have stopped taking pain medication and feel you could 
respond in an emergency
•Walking is good because it helps your muscles get stronger and 
improves blood flow. Start with short walks.  If you can, go a 
little further each time, letting comfort be your guide.  
•Try not to go up and downstairs too much in the first weeks.  
Use stairs only once or twice a day until your incision is fully 
healed and you are back to your usual strength.
•Avoid things that may constrict blood flow or put pressure on 
your incision, such as tight shoes, socks or knee highs.
•Do not take a tub bath or swim until your staples are removed 
and your wound is healed. 
•When you sit, keep your leg elevated to reduce swelling.
•If swelling in your leg is getting worse, lie down with your 
leg up on a pillows.  If your swelling continues, please call 
your surgeon.  You may be instructed to use special elastic 
bandages or stockings.
•Try not to sit in the same position for a long while.  For 
example, ___ go on a long car ride. 
•You may go outside.  But avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
•You may resume sexual activity after your incisions are well 
healed.

Your incision

•Your incision may be slightly red around the stitches or 
staples.  This is normal.
•It is normal to have a small amount of clear or light red 
fluid coming from your incision.
This will decrease and stop in a few days.  If it does not stop, 
or if you have a lot of fluid coming out., please call your 
surgeon.
•You may shower 48 hours after your surgery.  Do not let the 
shower spray right on the incision,  Let the soapy water run 
over the incision, then rinse.  Gently pat the area dry.  Do not 
scrub the incision,  Do not apply ointment or lotions to the 
incision.
•You do not need to cover the incision if there is no drainage, 
 If there is a small amount of drainage, put a small sterile 
gauze or Bandaid over the incison.
•It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision,  This 
will go away as your wound heals. 
•Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for 6 months.  
This will help keep the scar from becoming discolored.
•Over ___ months, your incision will fade and become less 
prominent.

Diet and Bowels
•It is normal to have a decreased appetite.  Your appetite will 
return over time.   Follow a well-balanced, health healthy diet, 
without too much salt and fat. 
•Prescription pain medicine might make you constipated.  If 
needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace) or gentle 
laxative (ask your pharmacist for recommendations).
Drinking more fluid may also help.
•If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or having pain 
moving your bowels, call your primary care physician.

You were treated by the Acute Care Surgery service at ___ 
___. You have multiple lacerations 
(cuts) on your body, rib fractures, and a left index fingertip 
fracture from a bite. You will need to be on antibiotics for 
this.

Please take your antibiotics as prescribed for 2 weeks.
You will also be received oxycodone for your injury. DO NOT 
DRINK ALCOHOL with this medication! Also do not drive a car or 
any machinery while taking this.

Go to your physician or the nearest Emergency Department if your 
condition worsens or you have any concerns.
Some warning signs are increased redness, fevers, chills, or any 
other concern. Follow up with your doctor in ___ days to 
reevaluate your finger. 

Rib Fractures:

* Your injury caused 5 rib fractures which can cause severe pain 
and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths because of 
the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).
