Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute appendicitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed 
laparoscopically.  You tolerated the procedure well and are now 
being discharged home with the following instructions:
Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

The ECMO speed was decreased and clamped with ongoing 
echocardiographic imaging and hemodynamic monitoring. 

Post-ECMO Decannulation
The patient is receiving milrinone and inhaled epoprostenol.
Immediately after decannulation there is a decrement in right 
ventricular contractility. At the case completion right 
ventricular systolic is moderate-to-severely depressed on noted 
support, with the greatest contractility occuring at the base. 
Right ventricular cavity size is increased compared to 
pre-decannulation. There is no significant change in the amount 
of tricuspid regurgitation. Left ventricular function remains 
mildly depressed. 

TTE (___)
The left atrium is normal in size. The interatrial septum is 
dynamic, but not frankly aneurysmal. There is no
evidence for an atrial septal defect by 2D/color Doppler. There 
is normal left ventricular wall thickness with a
normal cavity size. There is mild-moderate left ventricular 
regional systolic dysfunction with septal dyskinesis
(see schematic) and mild global hypokinesis of the remaining 
segments. The visually estimated left ventricular ejection 
fraction is 35%. Moderately dilated right ventricular cavity 
with SEVERE global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic valve 
leaflets (?#) appear structurally normal. The mitral valve 
leaflets appear structurally normal. There is tricuspid 
regurgitation present (could not be qualified). Due to acoustic
shadowing, the severity of tricuspid regurgitation may be 
UNDERestimated. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 
is high normal. There is a trivial pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Right ventricular cavity 
dilation with severe free wall hypokinesis. Normal left 
ventricular cavity size with septal dyskinesis. Trivial 
pericardial effusion.

The coronary circulation is right dominant.
LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a large 
caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into the Left Anterior 
Descending and Left Circumflex systems. There is a 40% stenosis 
in the mid and distal
segments.
LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the

The Inferior lateral of the OM, arising from the proximal

Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. If your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, 
you must keep that area dry for 10 days. 
•You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•If you were on a medication such as Coumadin (Warfarin), or 
Plavix (clopidogrel), or Aspirin, prior to your injury,do not 
resume these until you are cleared by your surgeon
•You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.
•Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
•Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or 
wheeze.
*You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons.  Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience an unusual discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under 
control within 24 hours.
*Your pain worsens or changes location.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*You develop any concerning symptoms.

advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may not drive or heavy machinery while taking narcotic analgesic 
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous 
physical activity and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 20 
lbs., until you follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct 
you further regarding activity restrictions.  Please also 
follow-up with your primary care physician.
 
Incision Care:
*Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your surgeon.
*You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap and warm 
water.  Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.  
Please remove any remaining strips ___ days after surgery.

hyponatremia. Urine Na 40, FeNa 0.8%, urine osm 242. Ddx broad 
but includes mineralocorticoid deficiency, renal tubular 
acidosis or poor PO intake ("tea and toast") if truly 
hypovolemic, and SIADH, hypothyroidism and glucocorticoid 
deficiency if truly euvolemic. Na increased to 125 after fluids. 
TSH was found to be normal at 0.82. Patient was placed on 1200 
cc/day fluid restriction and sodium corrected to 130 by the end 
of hospitalization. Ms. ___ was sent home with ___ services for 
weekly sodium monitoring. 
    
# Lethargy/Weakness: Patient reportedly less responsive this 
morning but alert and responsive upon evaluation. No focal 
neurological deficits to suggest evolving stroke. Likely 
secondary to hyponatremia and suboptimal PO intake. As sodium 
and PO intake improved, patient was noted by family to return to 
her baseline level of mentation.
 
# Chest pain: Patient without known CAD and with a history of 
substernal chest pain ___ GERD. GERD is likely etiology. In an 
elderly woman with poorly-controlled HTN and evidence of LVH on 
EKG and cardiomegaly on CXR, cardiac etiology was a concern but 
ruled out with normal EKG, negative serial troponins, and ECHO 
demonstrating symmetric LVH, EF of 70%. Home omeprazole was 
continued without resolution of pain. GI was consulted. Barium 
swallow showed evidence of esophageal dysmotility. EGD was 
negative for stricture or obstruction and a deep esophageal 
biopsy was taken. There is no plan for manometry as patient may 
not tolerate the procedure, though GI suspects she may have 
early achalasia and recommends soft dysphagia diet for treament 
of pain. If pain or symptoms progress, patient may consider 
botox injections down the road. 

# HTN: BP 180s on admission, although usually 130-150s at home. 
Patient is asymptomatic. We continued her home atenolol 25 mg 
BID throughout the hospitalization and held her home lisinopril 
due to hyponatremia. She had occasional SBPs in the 170s-190s, 
though remained asymptomatic. By discharge, her SBPs were in the 
140s-160s for over 24 hours.

stenosis. Patient not on chronic pain medications at home, 
although pain responsive to Tylenol. Her pain was managed with 
Tylenol ___ mg TID thoughout her hospital stay.

of her chest pain.

and chest pain now thought to be due to esophageal dysfunction.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with no known pmhx and was found down by 
family today and presented to an OSH in sepsis. She was 
transferred to ___ for further evaluation and is being 
admitted to the ___ for c/f septic shock and altered mental 
status.

# Sepsis concern
# Skin and soft tissue infection: R chest wall mass seen by 
breast surgery in ED, who felt not likely to be source of 
sepsis. 
# C/f necrotizing fasciitis: CT pelvis with area of soft tissue 
stranding with gas collection in L. groin as groin crease 
reaches perineum (5.8x2.5cm).
# UTI: U/A c/f UTI
# R. hepatic nodule 
Patient presents with elevated lactate and metabolic acidosis 
with multiple concerning infectious sources. Notably she has 
several skin lesions on R chest wall, R axilla, and L groin. She 
has an overlying 2.0 cm of irregular opacification in the right 
hepatic lobe which was indeterminate. She has blood and urine 
cultures which were drawn on admission, and she is being broadly 
covered with IV vancomycin, zosyn, and clindamycin. Surgery team 
did not feel that surgical intervention was indicated. Her 
lactate trended down with fluids from 4.1 on admission to 2.8 on 
___ AM. Although an ongoing issue is to follow up with 
radiology to better characterize the hepatic lesion, this 
ultimately may not be within the patient's goals of care. 

# Right chest wall mass: 
# Left axillary masses: 
Patient was found to have right chest wall mass extending into 
axilla (14.4x13.1cm) with exophytic mass over R. breast, along 
with multiple axillary, anterior chest wall, R. supraclavicular 
masses concerning for inflammatory breast cancer. She also has 
L. axillary masses c/f metastatic disease. Breast surgery was 
consulted for possibility of bedside core biopsy. Patient's 
family has determined that this would ultimately be within their 
goals even if only for diagnostic purposes. Her imaging and 
presentation is most consistent with metastatic breast cancer; 
there is no acute indication for debridement of the chest would 
per surgery and her family feels that palliative chemotherapy 
would not be within goals of care. Following breast biopsy, they 
would consider transitioning to comfort measures only.

#DVT/PE
On presentation had CT torso with DVT and PE. She was maintained 
on heparin drip with normal oxygen saturations.

#Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis
#Lactic Acidosis               
Presented with 7.___, HCO3 7, AG 36. Appears to be improving 
s/p IVF. Likely ___ elevated lactate (4.1) at admission. ___ 
also have some component of renal failure vs. uremia, but 
unclear since her medical history is largely unknown to us at 
this time. Less likely DKA, as blood sugars have been wnl. 
Lactate is downtrending with fluids.

___
Cr 1.9 at admission, though unclear what patient's baseline Cr 
is. Per family, she has been increasingly oliguric over the last 
three months. She received over 6L fluids at OSH and in the ED. 
Her creatinine has been stable at 1.8.

# Encephalopathy
# Altered mental status
Patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. There may be 
some contribution of infection to her mental status. She 
received olanzapine in the ED but otherwise has no received 
significant sedating pain medications. There is a possibility 
that she has metastatic disease to the brain; family requests an 
MRI.

#Social Issues
Reportedly estranged from family members until recently. Unclear 
what her supports are. SW consulted in the ED. Notified family 
and sister ___ is at bed side.

#Poor IV ___
RN tried multiple times to get access, pt is difficult to draw 
labs from. Unable to place PICC or midline due to extensive 
axillary masses.

GOALS OF CARE:
After reviewing her clinical course in the ICU, the family met 
with the ICU team.  The decision was made to transition the 
patient to comfort measures only.  All medications were stopped 
other than for comfort.  There were no more lab draws or vital 
signs.  Season's hospice was consulted and the patient was 
transferred to home with hospice care.  She is DNR/DNI/DNH going 
forward.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old man who presented with cauda equina 
syndrome and underwent laminectomy. Post op developed b/l DVT 
and PE.
.
Cauda Equina Syndrome: Mr. ___ was evaluated in the EW and 
noticed to have lower extremity weakness, numbness and decreased 
rectal tone. An MRI was obtained which showed a cauda equina 
syndrome at L3-4. He was taken to the OR for surgical 
intervention consisting of a decompression at L3-4.  Please see 
operative report for details.Post-operatively he was given pain 
medication and antibiotics.  He continued to have a drop foot on 
the left similar to pre-op.  He failed a voiding trial and the 
foley catheter was reinserted.  POD three he described calf 
pain.  Lower extremity ultrasound was obtained and showed 
bilateral DVTs.  He was transfered to the medical service for 
further management of his coumadin therapy (see below). Prior to 
discharge the patient was trialed without his foley catheter. He 
was able to void small amounts although sequential bladder scans 
showed large residuals. The day of discharge, the patient had a 
post-void residual of >1,000mls and the decision was made to 
discharge the patient with a foley catheter and leg bag. He will 
follow-up up with his primary care physician and likely be 
referred to urology for further management. Neuro exam on 
discharge remarkable for LLE with decreased sensation over the 
dorsum of the foot and anterior shin, cannot flex or extend left 
heel or wiggle left toes.
.
Pulmonary Embolism: Post-op the patient was noted to have calf 
pain and swelling. Underwent lower extremity US that showed b/l 
DVTs. The patient was HD stable and started on heparin bridge to 
coumadin. Had sinus tachycardia but not other ECG changes. The 
decision was made initially not to pursue definitive diagnosis 
of PE given HD stability. However, the patient remained 
tachycardic and began to have a rising WBC count. Also with 
worsening tachycardia. Underwent CTA that showed right basilar 
PE. There was no change in management. The patient was 
discharged on coumadin with a therepeutic INR and plans to 
continue warfarin for a 6 month course.
.

starting on ___. Never had any localizing Sx. Extensive w/u 
including UA, CTA, CT of surgical site were initially 
unremarkable. Prior to discharge the patient c/o burning with 
urination and he was found to have a UTI. Treated with a 14 days 
course of cipro. WBC had stabilized and started improving.

Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: POSTERIOR Lumbar 
Decompression  

 
Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
for comfort when you are walking. You may take it off when 
sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal home medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions:

INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Weight bearing as tolerated of left lower extremity, in 
multipodus or aircast boot

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add  oxycodone 5mg as needed for increased pain. Aim to 
wean off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an 
example on how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 325 daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB
Physical Therapy:
WBAT LLE
functional mobility
patient/caregiver education
balance training
DC planning
ROM
Treatments Frequency:
Any staples or superficial sutures you have are to remain in 
place for at least 2 weeks postoperatively.  Incision may be 
left open to air unless actively draining.  If draining, you may 
apply a gauze dressing secured with paper tape.  You may shower 
and allow water to run over the wound, but please refrain from 
bathing for at least 4 weeks postoperatively.

Brief Hospital Course:
BRIEF HISTORY:

The patient is a ___ w/ HBV, HCV, substance abuse disorder with 
active intravenous drug use, presenting w/ 3 weeks of back pain. 
On presentation, a CT scan and MRI of the lumbar spine 
demonstrated a large epidural abscess compressing the cauda 
equina nerve roots, with associated L5/S1 
discitis/osteomyelitis. The patient was started on IV vancomycin 
and cefepime for broad spectrum coverage, and treated with IV 
dilaudid for pain control. She underwent an anterior and 
posterior approach epidural abscess drainage and L5-S1 vertebral 
body washout with the installation of hardware for structural 
support. Cultures were drawn intraoperatively which grew Staph 
Aureus, matching the blood cultures from the OSH. With this 
data, cefepime was discontinued, and the patient was continued 
on Vancomycin for coverage of both MSSA and MRSA. The cultures 
eventually spectated to MRSA and the patient was continued on 
vancomycin. 

For pain control post operatively, the acute pain service was 
consulted who managed a ketamine drip for 48 hours. In addition, 
the pt was given a Dilaudid PCA, Acetaminophen 1000mg, and 
Gabapentin 600mg. When the pain was better controlled, the 
patient was started on an oral regimen, with IV dilaudid PRN. 
The patient also developed an acute on chronic anemia, with a 
hemoglobin of 6.4, for which she was transfused one unit of 
pRBCs. The patient continued to have pain control issues and was 
maintain on IV and PO dilaudid. On ___, the patient continued 
to spike fevers. A CT abdomen/ pelvis was done, which showed a  
new 4 cm fluid collection with peripheral enhancement and 
stranding medial to the bifurcation of the left common iliac 
artery, worrisome for infection. On ___, ___ placed drains in and 
drained a superior, inferior, and abdominal collection. 

The patient then had resolution of her fevers, but worsening 
pain. Chronic pain was consulted and her regimen was changed to 
Morphine ___ 15mg q4h and her none opioid medications were 
optimized. Patient was seen by social work for discussion of 
long term treatment plans of Opioid Use disorder. The patient 
preferred suboxone and on ___ her opioids and diazepam were 
stopped. On ___ when the patient's ___ was 8, the patient 
received one 4mg dose of suboxone around noon. Soon after she 
became anxious and stated she wanted to leave AMA. Infectious 
disease, the ___ medicine attending, and social work spoke 
to the patient extensively about the risks of leaving AMA, 
including the danger of leaving with an incomplete treatment of 
discitis/osteomyelitis, particularly in the setting of having 
hardware in place. Patient still decided to leave AMA after 
hearing all the risks of leaving, including death and worsening 
infections. Patient was redosed on her suboxone to 10mg total. 
She watched a video and was counseled on clean injection 
techniques and Naloxone use. Her PICC line was pulled and she 
was given a script for one month of Rifampin 300mg BID, bactrim 
DS 2 tabs BID, and naloxone and told to come for ID follow-up. 
Also encouraged to immediately report to the ER at ___ 
___ for any serious problems.

#) Epidural abscess  
#) Discitis/osteomyelitis  
The patient has a history of active IVDU, and presented with 
back pain, found to have L5/S1 discitis/osteomyelitis with 
associated epidural abscess associated with compression of the 
cauda equina nerve roots. Imaging also demonstrated an 
associated right paravertebral abscess and small presacral 
abscesses. She was started on vancomycin and cefepime for 
empiric coverage, and underwent an anterior and posterior 
approach, L5 vertebral body washout and spidural abscess 
drainage. Pt continued to have reassuring neuro exam throughout 
her preoperative and postoperative course, never demonstrating 
evidence of cauda equina syndrome. OSH blood cultures were found 
to  staph aureus, which matched the intraoperative cultures 
taken. Per ID recs, antibiotic therapy was narrowed to 
Vancomycin alone for MSSA and MRSA coverage until speciation.

Also added rifampin on ___ for synergy in regimen. On ___ 
patient chose to leave AMA and her PICC line was pulled. ID 
recommended Bactrim DS 2 tablets BID and rifampin 300mg BID, 
along with follow-up in ___ clinic.

pain service following. She was originally on a ketamine drip

and hydromorphone (Dilaudid) 0.36 mg IVPCA. When pain was well

dilaudid for breakthrough pain. Pt was also having abdominal 
pain post operatively, with concern for both post op ileus as 
well as opiate induced constipation. KUB was not concerning, and 
pt was treated with an aggressive bowel regimen, and 
methylnaltrexone. The regimen was transitioned to Morphine 15mg 
q4h for pain and non-opioid treatment was optimized. Patient 
then had withdrawal of opioid and benzodiazepine the medication 
on ___ for the preparation of suboxone treatment on ___. 
Patient left AMA without prescriptions for pain medication.

#)Intraabdominal collection-
Patient continued to have fevers after surgery, so was taken by 
___ for a drainage and drain placement on ___. Fever defervesced. 
A repeat CT scan showed improvement of the lateral collections, 
but persistence of the largest collection. No repeat imagining 
was recommended at that time, unless the patient continued to 
have fevers.

#) Anemia  
Pt’s baseline Hgb ___, previously thought to be secondary to 
iron and B12 deficiency. On admission, the pt’s Hgb was 6.9 and 
normocytic. Hgb dropped to 6.4 during hospitalization with no 
signs of active bleeding, and no evidence of hemolysis. Pt was 
transfused one unit of pRBCs with a good response. Continued to 
have low hg, but stable. Work up included testing for hemolysis 
and iron studies which were unrevealing. Thought to be 
multifactorial, including nutritional and secondary to 
inflammation.

#) Opiate use disorder: The patient was seen by the addiction 
specialist several times throughout the hospital stay who 
recommended continuously assessed the patient's readiness to 
start long term OUD treatment. Patient preferred suboxone to 
methadone, though had previously tried both and relapsed. The 
patient was nervous to start treatment, but stated "it has to 
get hard before it gets easier." On ___, morphine and valium 
was stopped and suboxone was initiated the next AM. Patient 
received 4mg, then 2mg more for ongoing withdrawal symptoms 
before leaving AMA. Was offered symptomatic medications, but did 
not want them. Was counseled on safe needle practices, naloxone 
use, and  The patient was educated on potential places to get 
suboxone and where to get needles. The patient stated she hoped 
to abstain from further drug use of heroine and cocaine, but 
felt that she was likely to relapse. 

#) Hydronephrosis- Patient was found to have hydronephrosis on 
CT scan. Her creatinine and urine function remained stable.

hospital and therefore you were sent with antibiotic pills. 
Below, please find an outline of your hospital course:

WHILE YOU WERE HERE:
- We found that there was an infection in the bones of your 
spine 
- We treated the infection with antibiotics
- The infection was so large, that you needed a surgery to wash 
out and drain the bones in your back
- After the surgery, we continued your antibiotics to kill the 
remaining bacteria 
- You were in severe pain after the surgery
- You were seen by our pain specialists, and we used very strong 
pain medicines through your IV to help control your pain
- When your pain started to improve, we switched you to oral 
pain control medicines
- The infection was caused by injecting drugs into your veins, 
so you met with our addiction specialist
- Together with the addiction specialist, you developed a plan 
to try to avoid using drugs after your discharge
- When your infection was under control with antibiotics and 
your pain medications were decreased and you were started on 
suboxone. 

WHEN YOU LEAVE:
- Please attend all of your follow up appointments
- Please take your antibiotics

It was a pleasure to care for you during your hospital stay.

tests, we have excluded diagnoses that would need urgent

most likely cause for your symptoms is a Bell's palsy - or an

the ___ cranial nerve, leading to dizziness. There is no

inflammation around the nerve. However, it may be several weeks 
before you notice sizeable improvements and return to baseline.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the hospital and taken to the 
Operating Room where she underwent a right lower lobe 
video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) wedge resection.  
She tolerated the procedure well and returned to the PACU in 
stable condition.  She maintained stable hemodynamics and her 
pain was minimal.  Her chest tube drained minimally and was 
without air leak.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor she continued to make 
good progress.  Her chest tube was removed on post op day #1 
without difficulty and her post pull film showed a tiny right 
apical space.  She was weaned off of oxygen easily and 
maintained room air saturations of 95%.  Her port sites were dry 
and her blood sugars were in good control on her pre op dose of 
Lantus.

She had some difficulty with urinary retention after her 
catheter was removed and eventuallt required replacement of the 
Foley catheter for 1000 cc's of urine. She underwent a second 
voiding trial and was able to urinate independently. She had 
some shortness of breath the morning of ___, so she was kept 
one more day for observation. Her breathing was much improved 
the morning of ___ with no more shortness of breath.  She 
was up and walking independently and tolerating a diabetic diet 
and was discharged home with instructions to follow up in the 
Thoracic Clinic in 2 weeks.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You came to the hospital because you were having terrible back 
pain and the doctors at the ___ hospital were concerned you 
might have an infection in your back. 

While you were here, we did not see any evidence of infection in 
your back, but we did notice you had fluid behind your lungs

stopped your blood pressure medications for a little while, and 
restarted some of them at lower doses. Your cardiologist should 
talk to you about these at your follow-up appointment next week. 


When you leave, you will go to rehab to work on your strength 
and mobility. You will continue to use your oxygen until you 
feel more comfortable off of it. 

It was a pleasure to care for you. We wish you the best in your 
recovery.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ right-handed woman with past 
medical history significant only for asthma and migraines who 
was admitted to our general neurology service after three weeks 
of painful dysesthesia that initially began in her left upper 
extremity along with an area of pruritis over her left face. The 
dysesthetic sensation then spread to her right upper extremity 
and then to her lower extremities bilaterally (distal-->proximal 
in LEs). Overt neurological deficits were minor, but some 
weakness was detected in her left finger extensors and her 
sensory exam was notable for decreased temperature as well as 
vibratory signs in the left lower extremity and decreased 
temperature signs in the left upper extremity. Pinprick 
sensation was normal throughout her extremities, abdomen, and 
back. Reflexes were normal except for absence at the patellae 
bilaterally (a stable finding throughout this admission). Gait 
and coordination were normal throughout this admission, and the 
patient was pleasant, conversational, and interactive / walking 
around the floor frequently with the exception of a few days 
after LP when she was suffering from a positional post-LP HA. 
She occasionally complained of lacking of a normal sensation of 
bladder fullness despite subseqent large-volume urination. No 
urinary frequency or incontinence at any time.

MRI of C-spine was repeated and previously-identified T2 signal 
in C-spine (parenchymal) was no longer seen, thought to be a 
motion artifact on ___ image. C5-6 right-sided foraminal 
disc-encroachment / narrowing was again seen.

LP was performed on the floor ___ with the following results: 
no polys or organisms seen on gram stain. Protein elevated at 79 
and oligoclonal bands were identified (9; uln is 5). 6 WBC-98% 
lymphs / 2 RBC (tube #4).

ESR was normal (5), but CRP was elevated at 18.9 (___). ___ 
was negative, as was sm antibody testing, RF, ANCA, and dsDNA -- 
all normal / negative. C3/C4 complement levels were within 
normal limits (138/26). Serum ACE negative, CXR (w.r.t. possible 
sarcoidosis) was normal. RPR was NR. Lyme serum and CSF antibody 
testing was negative. HIV serum Ab screen was negative. No 
abnormality was identified on SPEP. IgA level was normal (189, 
w.r.t. IVIG pre-planning). TSH 0.73 / fT4 1.2 (wnl both). B12 
was wnl at 444.

Gabapentin was started at 300mg tid and up-titrated to 400mg qid 
with some relief. Her pain control was augmented with Vicodin 
PRN, which was used frequently. Given the peripheral/radicular 
localization of the patient's dysesthetic polyneuropathy and 
mild weakness on exam, and after an EMG found mild abnormalities 
c/w GBS variant, and after no lesions could be identified 
consistent with a demyelinating intra-axial lesion such as MS 
could be identified on MRI, a presumptive diagnosis was made of 
a sensory-predominant GBS variant. Mrs. ___ was then treated 
with IVIG 0.4g/d over five days, with no side effects, but also 
minimal to no improvement of her dysesthesia. Neurologic exam 
was normal (no weakness could be detected) by the time of 
discharge. She was discharged to home with gabapentin and 
Vicodin for pain relief, and instructed to follow up with Dr. 
___ in Neurology clinic in ___.

-finished prednisone 1d PTA (started by PCP in attempt to

Brief Hospital Course:

. 
Her daughter, ___, who is her healthcare proxy came in on the 
day after admission for a family meeting with the team and 
social workers.  At that meeting it was decided the best course 
of action was to continue with comfort care, as previously 
decided.  
. 
#Agitation:  The agitation was most likely related to terminal 
disease and azotemia from ARF found on lab studies drawn in the 
emergency department.  The patient was continued on Ativan and 
Zyprexa to decrease agitation.  As pain control may have been 
contributing to her agitation, the patient was placed on Tylenol 
and morphine PRN for grimacing, increased HR/RR or any other 
evidence of pain.  The palliative care team was also consulted 
to help with symptom management.  
.  
#ARF:  The patient was found to have an elevated creatinine from 
her baseline on labs checked in the ___.  There is a likely 
component of prerenal from poor PO intake vs. renal, possibly 
obstructive from intraabdominal process. Per family request,  
the patient received IVF briefly. She did not have a Foley 
placed as this was against the family's wishes. 
.  
#Metastatic Colon Cancer: The patient was on home hospice. She 
was brought in partly because of difficulty in watching patient 
become agitated.  She was treated for pain with Tylenol RTC and 
Morphine PRN for grimacing, increased HR/RR or any other 
evidence of pain.  She was also started on a scopolamine patch 
to decrease secretions.  Her secretions were treated with 
scopolamine patch and Levsin as well as oxygen by nasal cannula 
for comfort. 

The patient was made comfort measures only and medications as 
above were started.
She died with her daughter at her bedside.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of HCV, ETOH abuse, and frostbite 
neuropathy, now presenting s/p clavicle fracture with ___ days 
of RUE weakness.

# Spinal canal stenosis: 
He had MRI of the right brachial plexus and C-spine which showed 
minimal compression of the brachial plexus but moderate spinal 
stenosis with deformity of the spinal cord from C4-C7. On ___ 
he underwent anterior cervical fusion with discectomy C4-5 and 
C5-6. The procedure was uncomplicated and he recovered well. His 
neurologic exam remained stable throughout his admission with no 
substantial improvement or worsening of his right upper 
extremity weakness. He was assessed by physical and occupational 
therapy. He will need outpatient follow-up with neurosurgery and 
neurology following his discharge. 

# EtOH Abuse / withdrawal: He presented in active withdrawal and 
was placed on a CIWA scale. Last reported drink was at 10:00 on 
the day of admission. Given symptomatic improvement the CIWA 
scale was subsequently discontinued, and he had no symptoms of 
alcohol withdrawal at time of discharge. Nutritional 
supplementation with multivitamins/thiamine/folate was given. He 
will need continued access to outpatient resources for treatment 
of alcohol dependence after discharge.

streptococcus. Physical therapy was consulted to assist in his 
mobility. A weight offloading shoe was provided to reduce 
pressure over the ulcerated area.

genotype. This may need to be further evaluated in the 
appropriate outpatient setting.

etiology. He had recent negative HIV test and TB test was 
negative a year ago. He may need further evaluation for this 
symptom in the appropriate outpatient setting.

returning to 160 by the time of discharge. Prophylactic heparin 
was discontinued, and anti-PF4 antibody was sent in the setting 
of intermediate probability for HITT and is pending at 
discharge. Known hepatitis C and cephalexin use might have 
contributed.

Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions/Information

•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•You may wash your hair only after sutures and/or staples have 
been removed. If your wound closure uses dissolvable sutures, 
you must keep that area dry for 10 days. 
•You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.  
•If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for 
anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with 
laboratory blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your 
PCP’s office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will 
not require blood work monitoring.
•If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure 
you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
•Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit. Do not do so until then.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home.
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•Any signs of infection at the wound site: increasing redness, 
increased swelling, increased tenderness, or drainage.
•Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

Follow-Up Appointment Instructions

•Please return to the office in ___ days (from your date of 
surgery) for removal of your staples/sutures and/or a wound 
check. This appointment can be made with the Nurse Practitioner. 
 Please make this appointment by calling ___. If you 
live quite a distance from our office, please make arrangements 
for the same, with your Primary Care Provider. 

****Please stop at the radiology file library in the Clinical 
Center ___ floor to pick up the CD that contains all ___ 
brain images. She will need this for radiation oncology team.

Discharge Instructions:
*  Your accident caused left anterior rib fractures ___ which 
can cause severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow 
breaths because of the pain.
 
*  You should take your pain medication as directed to stay 
ahead of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep 
breaths. If the pain medication is too sedating take half the 
dose and notify your physician.
 
*  Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
*  You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to 
hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing 
and deep breathing.
 
*  Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
*  Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
*  Do NOT smoke

*  Do NOT drink alcohol
 
*  If your doctor allows, non steroidal antiinflammatory drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
*  Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs ( crepitus ).

initiated for this and given her fever on presentation, that her

Brief Hospital Course:
Ortho course:

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:

Transferred to ___ for pressors requirement, intubated & 
sedated.  He was brought to the FICU due to obesity and 
hypoventilation with Pickwickian syndrome.  His FICU course is 
described below.

# Respiratory failure: The patient has Pickwickian syndrome 
(obesity hypoventilation syndrome) and was brought to the unit.  
Patient was extubated POD2. He was still sleepy, however his 
ABGs were close to his baseline.  Overnight, he used CPAP 
without issue. The patient uses 3L NC at home; however, in the 
ICU he was weaned to 1L NC.

# Anemia: Patient's hemoglobin dropped to 6.7, the patient was 
transfused 3 units of blood.  His hemoglobin was 7.2 after 2 
units. Ortho evaluated the patient and there was no concern for 
an acute bleed.

The patient was eventually transferred to the floor in stable 
condition.

ID was consulted for infection & recommended Ancef x 6 weeks on 
discharge.  OR cultures grew MSSA.  PICC was placed by ___ on 
___ for long-term antibiotic treatment.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Lovenox (40 mg BID) for 
DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The foley was 
removed and the patient was voiding independently thereafter. 
The overlying dressing was removed on POD#2 and the Silverlon 
dressing was found to be clean and dry. The patient was seen by 
physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout the hospital 
course and repleted accordingly. At the time of discharge the 
patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling well.  The 
patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The patient's 
hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately controlled on 
an oral regimen. The operative extremity was neurovascularly 
intact and the wound was benign.

The patient's weight-bearing status is non-weight bearing left 
lower extremity.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills.

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.

7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Lovenox for four (4) 
weeks to help prevent deep vein thrombosis (blood clots).  If 
you were taking aspirin prior to your surgery, it is OK to 
continue at your previous dose while taking anticoagulation 
medication.  ___ STOCKINGS x 6 WEEKS.

9. WOUND CARE: It is okay to shower five days after surgery but 
no tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after 
your four (4) week checkup. You may place a dry sterile dressing 
on the wound, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound 
regularly for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow 
drainage. Staples will be removed by the visiting nurse or rehab 
facility in two (2) weeks.

10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks, and staple removal at two weeks after 
surgery.

11. ACTIVITY: Non weight bearing left lower extremity. No 
strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up appointment. 
 Mobilize frequently.

12. PICC CARE: Per protocol

at: ___ R.N.s at ___.

closed.

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after being hit by a car you 
had a heart attack. We took you to a procedure called a cardiac 
catheterization to look at the arteries that supply the heart 
muscle with oxygenated blood which revealed that you had fresh 
clot in your right coronary artery blocking that artery. You 
also have two other blockages in the LAD or left anterior 
descending artery as well as the left circumflex artery. We 
fixed the right coronary artery by placing two stents to open 
the blockage as we thought that was the blockage causing the 
problem. You still have two blockages that we will treat for now 
with medications but becuase of this it is very important that 
you report any symptoms of chest pain to Dr. ___ if 
unrelieved call ___.
 
Because of your heart attack you are now on the following 
medications:
1. Aspirin 81mg daily.
2. Atorvastatin 80mg daily (an anticholesterol medication)
3. Plavix 75 mg daily : This keeps the stent open and should not 
be stopped for any reason unless Dr. ___ says to 
stop it. Stopping this medication early COULD cause you to have 
another lifethreatening heart attack)
4. Metoprolol Xl 100mg daily: This decreases the workload of the 
heart.
5. Valsartan 80mg daily: This medication decreases the pressure 
the heart has to pump against. 
6. Nitroglycerine as needed with chest pain: these are tabs you 
place under your tongue and use only when you have chest pain. 
It is important that if you require this medication because you 
are having chest pain more with increased frequency you should 
contact your cardiologist Dr. ___. 
 
At the time of the heart attack your heart pumping function was 
also depressed or decreased. This is called heart failure. The 
drugs, Valsartan and Metorprolol decrease the workload of the 
heart and should help prevent worseing of your heart failure.
 
Because of your open fracture of your right leg you will need to 
change the dressing every day. If you notice drainage from the 
site that is purulent or with pus you need to call the surgeons 
and be seen. OTher signs of infection are listed below as danger 
signs.
 
Because of your history fo alcoholism it is really important 
that you continue your plans to attend AA and avoid alcohol 
consumption. Becasue of chronic alcohol intake you were in need 
of electrolytes to supplement your poor state of nutrition. You 
should continue taking a multivitamin and thiamine daily.

pressures were clearly needed. In supine REM BIPAP SV auto

sats 88% and occasional respiratory events but while in NREM

stayed at 95% or greater. There was no evidence of periodic
breathing with the addition of NV mask.

EPAP 12 PS min 7 PS max of 13 with 6L O2 results in very good
control of SDB in supine NREM and acceptable control in supine
REM. There was no evidence of periodic breathing, albeit with 
the

be performed to identify optimal settings upon discharge from

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___. You were admitted to our hospital for 
your incarcerated ventral hernia. You had an exploratory 
laparotomy, lysis of adhesions, ventral hernia repair with mesh 
and component separation on ___ without complications. You 
tolerated the procedure well and are ambulating, stooling, 
tolerating a regular diet, and your pain is controlled by pain 
medications by mouth. You are now ready to be discharged to 
home. Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a speedy 
and uneventful recovery. 

ACTIVITY:
- Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
- You may climb stairs. You should continue to walk several 
times a day. 
- You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
- You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. 
Slowly increase your activity back to your baseline as 
tolerated.
- Heavy exercise may be started after 6 weeks, but use common 
sense and go slowly at first. 
- No heavy lifting (10 pounds or more) until cleared by your 
surgeon, usually about 6 weeks. 
- Continue to wear your abdominal binder.
- You may resume sexual activity unless your doctor has told you 
otherwise.

HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
- You may feel weak or "washed out" for 6 weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
- You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during the surgery.

YOUR BOWELS:
- Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medicine 
such as oxycodone. If needed, you may take a stool softener 
(such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk 
of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
- If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain 
moving the bowels, call your surgeon.
- After some operations, diarrhea can occur. If you get 
diarrhea, don't take anti-diarrhea medicines. Drink plenty of 
fluids and see if it goes away. If it does not go away, or is 
severe and you feel ill, please call your surgeon.

PAIN MANAGEMENT:
- You are being discharged with a prescription for oxycodone for 
pain control. You may take Tylenol as directed, not to exceed 
3500mg in 24 hours. Take regularly for a few days after surgery 
but you may skip a dose or increase time between doses if you 
are not having pain until you no longer need it. You may take 
the oxycodone for moderate and severe pain not controlled by the 
Tylenol. You may take a stool softener while on narcotics to 
help prevent the constipation that they may cause. Slowly wean 
off these medications as tolerated. 
- Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain 
is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.

If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon: 
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- chest pain, pressure, squeezing, or tightness
- cough, shortness of breath, wheezing
- pain that is getting worse over time or pain with fever
- shaking chills, fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
- nausea and vomiting, inability to tolerate fluids, food, or 
your medications
- if you are getting dehydrated (dry mouth, rapid heart beat, 
feeling dizzy or faint especially while standing)
-any change in your symptoms or any symptoms that concern you

Additional: 
*- pain that is getting worse over time, or going to your chest 
or back
*- urinary:  burning or blood in your urine or the inability to 
urinate

MEDICATIONS:
- Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just 
as you did before, unless you have been told differently.
- If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not 
to take, please call your surgeon. 

WOUND CARE: 
-You may shower with any bandage strips that may be covering 
your wound. Do not scrub and do not soak or swim, and pat the 
incision dry. If you have steri strips, they will fall off by 
themselves in ___ weeks. If any are still on in two weeks and 
the edges are curling up, you may carefully peel them off.  Your 
staples will be removed by your surgeon at your follow up 
appointment. 
 Do not take baths, soak, or swim for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by your surgical team. 
-Notify your surgeon is you notice abnormal (foul smelling, 
bloody, pus, etc) or increased drainage from your incision site, 
opening of your incision, or increased pain or bruising. Watch 
for signs of infection such as redness, streaking of your skin, 
swelling, increased pain, or increased drainage. 

Please call with any questions or concerns. Thank you for 
allowing us to participate in your care. We hope you have a 
quick return to your usual life and activities. 

-- Your ___ Care Team

Discharge Instructions
Dr. ___ 

Activity
• You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we

should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding 
from your groin.
• You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
• Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) 
days after your procedure.
• You make take a shower.

Medications
• Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
• You have been instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a 
day and Brilinta. If so, do not take any other products that 
have aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain 
Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office.
• You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
• If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again 
three (3) days after your procedure.

Care of the Puncture Site
• Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
• You may use a band-aid if you wish.

What You ___ Experience:
• Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
• Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
• Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few 
weeks.
• Fatigue is very normal
• Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
• Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the puncture 
site. 
• Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
• Constipation
• Blood in your stool or urine
• Nausea and/or vomiting
• Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
• Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
• Seizures
• Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
• Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Brief Hospital Course:
Medical:  The patient was medically cleared in the emergency 
department prior to admission and labs were taken including CBC, 
BMP, liver panel, TSH, and urinalysis, vit B12, folate and RPR.  
Vitals were checked daily.  During her hospitalization, the 
patient demonstrated difficulty remembering where she put her 
possessions particularly at night time, and one two occasions 
believed others patients had taken her things.  A 
neuropsychology screen was done by Dr. ___ on the unit which 
showed nonspecific memory impairment. The patient was referred 
for outpatient neuropsychological testing and Behavioral 
Neurology follow up to better characterize her cogntive 
deficits.  Of note, the patient reports a family history of 
Alzeihmer's as well as a history of head trauma as a youth.

Psychopharm:  The patient was admitted on a regimen of Zoloft, 
Ativan, and Aricept.  We continued all three of these 
medications and increased her dosage of Zoloft from 50mg daily 
to 125 mg daily in order to maximize the anti depressant effect. 
 She tolerated this increase well and reported no side effects.  
Ms. ___ had two episodes of paranoia regarding her roommate, 
during which she felt that she overrheard her wanting to attack 
her with brass knuckles.  Due to this incident as well as 
corroboration from the family regarding transient paranoia at 
home, we started the patient on risperdal 1 mg qHS. The patient 
tolerated Risperdal well and did not have any further paranoid 
incidents on the unit.  

Psychosocial:  The patient was initially somewhat isolative but 
became increasingly visible on the unit and interactive during 
her stay.  She participated in groups and individual therapy.  
After the first day, the patient denied suicidality and stated 
that her mood was somewhat improved.  She also stated that she 
would be willing to go back to live with her son rather than 
going to a shelter.  There was a family meeting where we 
addressed the patient's living situation with her two daughters 
and her son's girlfriend.  This was quite productive. We had a 
second meeting which included the above family members as well 
as the son concerning the patient's memory difficulties, 
neurological follow-up. We provided the family with 
psychoeducation regarding the patient's depression and our 
finding of memory impairments.

Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions

•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•You may wash your hair only after sutures have been removed.  
•You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
•You have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure 
medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory 
blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your PCP’s 
office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
•Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home, unless you have been instructed not to. 
**You may restart your home regimen of Plavix on ___. You 
may resume taking your baby aspirin on ___.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
•Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.
